repnme.cdata!: Bangladesh - Jute Sector Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Jute Sector Adjustment
            Credit Project in Bangladesh were as follows: overall
            outcome of the project was rated unsatisfactory, project
            sustainability was unlikely, the Bank performance was rated
            satisfactory, and the performance of the Borrower was rated
            deficient. Lessons learned from the project are: 1) the
            program confirmed the experience elsewhere that broad
            internalization of the reform program by the borrower and
            its executing agencies, accompanied by solid political
            commitment and consensus at the highest levels of decision
            making are essential ingredients for any successful
            International Development Association (IDA) structural
            reform operation; 2) it is important that IDA and the
            Borrower reach a common understanding as to the possible
            outcome of a program. In the case of Jute Sector Adjustment
            Credit (JSAC), IDA's perception that the jute
            industrial output could decrease substantially was different
            from that of the Government of Bangladesh (GOB's) that
            total output would remain constant; and 3) in cases of
            significant downsizing of installed industrial capacity it
            is important to provide a social safety net for the benefit
            of displaced workers as was recognized under the Program.
            However, it is also important to consider ways to mitigate
            the adverse effects of the industrial restructuring on
            livelihood in the associated sectors -- e.g. farmers in the
            case of jute mill restructuring.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Jute Sector Adjustment Credit
            : request for inspection

abstracts.cdata!:
The Request for Inspection for the Jute
            Sector Adjustment Credit in Bangladesh, filed by CEOs and
            shareholders of the jute mills, states the Bank has failed
            to comply with its own policies and procedures and has
            failed in requiring the Government to follow contractual
            agreements.  The Jute Sector Adjustment Credit (JSAC) is a
            project meant to redevelop the large jute industry into a
            smaller, but profitable, industry, and to initiate a
            privatization program that will turn publicly owned mills
            into private ones.  The Request specifies how the Bank has
            violated its own policies, including: lack of support for
            the private sector and an unwillingness to take seriously
            the concerns of the private sector of the jute industry.
            The Request specifies that the Bank has given more
            opportunity to the public mills and not consulted the
            private sector on issues such as wage policy reform,
            privatization of public mills and technical assistance and
            training.  The private sector mills have lost operating
            capacity based on denied working capital and decrease in
            loom operation.

            Request for Inspection

repnme.cdata!:
Bagladesh - Jute Sector Adjustment Credit :
            Management Response

abstracts.cdata!:
The Management Response to the
            Inspection Panel for the Jute Sector Adjustment Credit in
            Bangladesh responds to the complaints that the Requesters
            have been adversely affected by a failure to policies and
            procedures.  The Response rejects these claims and states
            that the failures and delays are a result of the Government
            of Bangladesh's inaction. The Response states that the
            complaints are out of the jurisdiction of the Inspection
            Panel since it cannot investigate actions that are the
            responsibility of other parties. The Response finds that all
            policies and procedures were followed correctly and that the
            requesters have failed to prove that any of the harms
            suffered are a direct result of violations of policy and procedures.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Jute Sector Adjustment Credit
            : Eligibility Report

abstracts.cdata!:
The Eligibility Report for the Jute
            Sector Adjustment Credit in Bangladesh examines the
            complaints and, after investigating the claims, concludes
            that the Request for Inspection is valid.  The complaints
            stem from a failure of the Bank to follow policy and
            procedure while implementing the Jute Sector Adjustment
            Credit (JSAC). Despite problems that are outlined in the
            Request for Inspection, the Panel does not recommend an
            investigation at this time. The Panel cites many different
            reasons, including issues with the other groups involved in
            the JSAC.  The Panel feels that an investigation would not
            solve any of the concerns.

Bangladesh - Jute Sector Adjustment Credit :
            Eligibility Report
